title: 113_hr3706
content: The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" aims to improve the investigation and prosecution of child abuse cases by increasing funding and enhancing accountability measures. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" enhances accountability for grants awarded under the subtitle by requiring audits to prevent misuse of funds by grantees. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" aims to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse of grant funds by grantees through mandatory exclusion and prioritizing eligible entities with no unresolved audit findings in the past 3 fiscal years. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" requires entities barred from receiving grants to repay improperly awarded funds to the Treasury and recoup costs from the grant recipient. Nonprofit organizations must meet specific requirements to be eligible for grants. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" mandates that nonprofit organizations awarded grants must disclose any offshore accounts used for tax avoidance and provide details on compensation practices for key personnel. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" requires nonprofit organizations receiving grants to disclose compensation practices, including the process, independent reviewers, comparability data, and conference expenditure limitations. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" mandates that Department funds exceeding $20,000 for conferences require prior written approval from designated officials, including cost estimates for all expenses. The Deputy Attorney General must submit an annual report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on approved conference expenditures.
